Gunshep(ph) is a young monk from a monastery in eastern Tibet.
He says that the protests in Lhasa inspired his fellow monks to hit the streets in protest.
(Through translator) The main problem is that in Tibetan areas, we don't have human rights or freedom of speech or religion.
People all over the world enjoy these rights, and we don't want to live out our days without them.
He says the protests later turned violent.
He spoke of Tibetans' frustration.
(Through translator) Nobody wants violence, but the Tibetan cause is losing momentum.
There's so little we can do.
We stage a peaceful protest or sit-in and the soldiers haul us off, and nobody outside Tibet hears about it.
The Tibetans of eastern Tibet are known for their fiercely independent ways and for leading the failed uprising against Beijing in 1959.
The Dalai Lama argues that Tibetan areas that are now part of four Chinese provinces should be part of a single autonomous region.
Beijing counters that those areas were never ruled by Lhasa, and that the Dalai Lama's argument proves that he really wants Tibetan independence, not just autonomy.
For now, the streets of Chengdu's Tibetan quarter are tensely quiet under a heavy police presence.
Many Tibetans say the unrest will continue until China's policies towards them change.
Gumba is among the many Tibetans who are pessimistic about what will happen when the Dalai Lama, who is 72, passes from the scene.
We Tibetans have been very - have been in a very peaceful way with the Chinese government.
I think it's because of his holiness the Dalai Lama.
He always tells us to be good people, to do good things.
If his holiness is not here to teach us good things, I think there will happen more violence.
Anthony Kuhn, NPR News, Chengdu, China.
It's the season for toy buying and that has retailers worried this year.
The U.S.
has recalled dozens of toys made in China, so retailers have stepped up their own testing before the products hit the shelves.
NPR's Anthony Brooks reports.
At stake is the public's trust in what they buy for their children.
To retailers, that means a lot of money is at risk in the form of lost business or lawsuits.
So many are taking steps to ensure that potentially harmful toys don't make it to their shelves.
Target, JC Penney and Wal-Mart, among other big stores, are pulling products and testing them to ensure they're safe.
Toys R Us now acquires suppliers to identify where their products were made and to certify that they've been tested for safety.
But Charles Margulis with the Center for Environmental Health at Oakland, California says consumers are still at risk.
Just before Thanksgiving we bought a hundred toys and tested them for lead and found nine of them with very high levels of lead and another 11 with levels of lead that could be a concern.
That's 20 percent of the toys that we bought just before Thanksgiving.
Margulis says not all stores test for safety.
He says there needs to be uniform federal standards that require all toy manufacturers and retailers to test their products.
The House and Senate are both drafting bills that would tighten testing standards and increase fines for selling unsafe products.
The bills would also allow states to enforce federal product safety laws.
That's opposed by manufacturers and retailers who fear would lead to more litigation.
Anthony Brooks, NPR News.
